description.narrative: In Bangladesh, national production of pulses such as lentil and mungbean within rice-based cropping is declining dramatically because of competition from more remunerative irrigated crops, and this has resulted in a drop in plant protein production that has become a major concern of Government. Pulses have been marginalised to the shrinking rainfed areas of low productivity - partly because of their susceptibility to biotic stresses - and pulse imports to fuel rising demand have overtaken production. Household livelihoods and diets can benefit by crop diversification through intensification, and as part of the drive to reinvigorate national pulse production this project will fit short-duration pulses (lentil, mungbean and field pea) into new cropping niches in western Bangladesh. This tailoring process involves introducing new super-short duration cultivars, the use of relay cropping and adoption of minimum tillage.
